text: So we're covering here the value of open source software.

text: Let me just give you an idea, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And probably you are closer to that than maybe some of the other audience members to whom I usually present, but you can think about a bunch of companies here, Google, Ford, Intel, John Deere, and we usually can just ask, what do they have in common?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, actually what they have in common is
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that among others, they are really examples of users and contributors to open source software.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we know that open source software is really a cornerstone of modern software development.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So 96% of firm code bases contain some form of open source software.

text: That's according to the software analytics company Synopsys.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And 76% of all code in firm code bases is actually open source software code.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's hugely important in cutting edge technologies, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, big data and analytics, and many other areas.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So one venture capitalist, Mark Anderson, once said, software is eating the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that was enhanced by Joseph Jacks,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: who you said saying open source is actually eating software faster than software is eating the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Just talking about the dominance of open source software, which just to give you the rough idea of the definition, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Open source software is software whose source code is publicly available, usually under some permissive license.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In particular, we are interested in free open source software very often, which is a public good.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's generally non-rival.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if I consume it, it's not less available for you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it's usually non-excludable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So basically, it's the ideal form of a public good that everybody can consume.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And often, you can really think of that as a global public good, like education.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: individuals and firms have used open source software and contribute to it substantially, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there has been a bunch of literature, especially by my co-author here, Frank Nigel, but also a lot of other people.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we are continuously working on better understanding the open source software ecosystem, companies and individuals that engage in it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now you're probably very familiar with this slide.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Maybe I've seen it too often, this kind of figure, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Where we can see this huge machinery of our modern digital infrastructure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then there is this little piece at the bottom, which is a project by some random person in Nebraska that has been thanklessly maintained since 2003.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what that tells you, right, there is first there is some huge dependency on some highly active individual, some open source maintainers without our without there could be a potential collapse of our modern digital infrastructure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And on top of that, the issue of the tragedy of the commons, which is
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that which is common to the greatest number gets the least amount of care, according to Aristotle, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there's some kind of free-riding potential, not only, but also, I think, issues that we observe anecdotally and which we also see here in the data as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now, why do we care about the value of open source software?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, I guess we care about the value of a lot of goods.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But here in particular, we do not know actually what's the value of open source software because it doesn't even come up in traditional
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Gross domestic product measures that are in accounting systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And also some firms may just not be aware of productivity and cost saving benefits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's why we are bringing out this paper to better understand the value of open source software, measuring the value here in a very simple way as the price times quantity, P times Q. And so here, open source software really is a problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The price of open source software is zero, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is no price.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is the actual measurement problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the quantity, well, it's infinitely replicable because the license allows for free copying and usage is not easily trackable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we have a problem on the price side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We have a problem on the quantity side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we're not saying that we're going to solve this problem, but we're saying we're going to try to make some inroads here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is in the spirit of what Warren Buffett said, price is what you pay and value is what you get.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So price could be one idea of value, but it's really not the actual value.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, we want to provide a value measure here because usually a lot of folks, managerial folks, firms working in companies, but really anybody wants to understand, wants to get an idea of how valuable something is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So because otherwise, people may not allocate resources towards it or do not really understand the importance of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we ask, how much would we lose really if open source software did not exist?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or ask differently, how much would it cost us to replicate the universe of open source code?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for prices, we're going to calculate the prices using
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: what we like to call a replacement value or so-called, you could also use purchase price.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for quantity, we will use two large data sets, the largest ones that we are aware of.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One is the census of open source software, which is inward facing towards within the company, the products that they are using and then reselling and then built with, which is
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: an outward-facing data set that is basically based on websites and the usage of open source software and websites.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, to measure the value of open source software, or really the value of anything that is difficult to measure, you could go about it in two ways.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You could go about it from the output market side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The output market would be the goods market from the firm's perspective, and you can just
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Let's say you have a good that has a price of zero, then you find a substitute good that actually has a positive price, and you may be able to impute that to get an understanding of what the value may be.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Nordhaus has famously made this very general case for
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: greenhouse gas emissions and Greenstein-Nagel have, for example, calculated the value of Apache servers being around $2 billion since that has been extended with web servers in general, the value being around $4.5 billion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they could do that because they have had some information on what the substitute good was.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that is very helpful, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they have information on usage of all of the web servers, but then we can only really look at one particular type of software here, web servers, and it's difficult to expand that because you would need to find a basket of goods, a gigantic basket for each of the open source software packages, and some are not
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: are really small pieces.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Some are larger pieces.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's difficult to find those substitute goods.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what we did is we're going to use the second approach, the input market approach or the labor approach.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So from a firm's perspective, you're going on the labor market and we're going to look at the replacement value via labor costs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You can think about that in the spirit of household innovations, bicycle and hippo.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The main idea here really is let's think about the housework that you are doing, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You're cleaning something, you're vacuuming in your house and you're not getting paid for that, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You just do that in your free time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's not going to add to GDP, but you could instead hire somebody and they could do the work
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and vacuum for you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that would be the price that it would cost to engage in this household activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then you could measure the value.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we are going to do a similar exercise.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we're not the first one here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is Blint and co-authors that have done a kind of similar exercise for the European Union.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Robins and co-authors have done an exercise for the United States where they estimated the supply side value being around 1 billion to 38 billion dollars.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We do this
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: not on the european or us level but we think about that as a global estimate but we are going to cut down and we're going to look at firm specific contributions so we're going to discard kind of the long tails of contributions that may um happen from from individual small contributions so that's where our estimates may differ so now the good thing about this approach is we have all of open source
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: we can use all of open source software and we can assign some kind of price by imputing the wage that it would cost to create this product.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the negative aspect is maybe it's difficult to get the usage information.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But now we're also approximating usage information through our two large data sets.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So now,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For our methodology, we're using really multiple counterfactuals.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, we are mainly using method two, but in one counterfactual, we're also going to use a part of method one a little bit, and I'm going to explain this in more detail here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So our first counterfactual is the supply side counterfactual.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's the idea that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: open source software as a concept just purely doesn't exist.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And now the whole code has to be rewritten once.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, we're doing that by looking at all open source packages that are used by companies in particular.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we think about addressing production externalities.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So like we are just holding constant people that are working one company are not going to move to another company and are not benefiting from the production of one piece of code when they are then producing another piece of code.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But they are just producing those pieces of code separately.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then we count the lines of codes per package and calculate
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: labor replacement value so which is for us in this case the value of from the supply side now if we can dive into a little bit how this labor replacement cost value works exactly after going through those three counterfactuals now the second counterfactual is well if the concept of open source doesn't exist anymore
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: now what would happen is maybe one firm would rewrite would would emerge and rewrite the code and then sell it to all of the other firms so um that's now we would just think about obtaining the information usage information that we have from both data sets on the packages we address
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Consumption, externalities, so there are no additional spillovers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then we sell the one seller.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: generates all of those packages and then they sell it at the market price p so here you can really see it's just the price times quantity over all of the packages minus the fixed cost that it takes to generate those packages which is really as a value from the supply side from the first counterfactual and the elasticity of demand here is around one we did some and that we set around one based on the literature but
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: we estimated it and varied it, so engage in some robustness checks that you can find in the paper as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the main idea is that we find an optimal price P here, give them all of the quantities, and then we can create, then we can get a measure of the overall value from a one seller demand side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, a third counterfactual is what we like to call the firm autarchy demand side.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is a concept
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: open source software again doesn't exist anymore now each firm has to write rewrite the code by themselves we again obtain all of the usage information address consumption externalities but now there's a single replacement idea within a firm so when you use when you use a product yes you can use it multiple time a package but we are really thinking of that we don't have to generate that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is no additional value that is being generated from using it additional times because you're just using, you can just freely move it within the company and there's no price for internally using it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now we calculate the value here by using the supply side value and multiplying it by all the times that it has been used each package for each of those companies.
